These underground passages are a place of pilgrimage, with visitors coming to venerate the relics and experience the serene, otherworldly atmosphere of the caves.

It has played a crucial role in the preservation and dissemination of Orthodox Christian traditions, theological scholarship, and religious art. The Lavra continues to be an active monastery, home to a community of monks who maintain the centuries-old spiritual practices that have been passed down through generations.

The High Castle is proximate to the\xa0centre\xa0of Lviv (see picture), formerly being surrounded by a fortification wall. The Castle Hill took its name from the High Castle (as opposed to the other, Low Castle), which used to be located on the hill from the 13th century to the late 19th century. The castle was a main defensive fort of the city during its existence.

As it follows from Rus' Chronicles, the first fortifying structures appeared on the Castle Hill in the time\xa0Halych-Volhynia, and were built by\xa0Leo I of Halych\xa0from wood. It was originally a wood and soil construction, as most others at that time. In 1259 by a request of Burunday Khan they were destroyed, but in 1270 were rebuilt. A new brick castle appeared on the hill in 1362 by the king Casmimir III. It became the residence of Polish nobles. The hill crests at 413 metres, and setting off on foot from Market Square it takes about 25 minutes to reach the top.

The path is perfectly walkable, if a little taxing on the upper reaches, when the slope becomes very sharp.

But a bit of persistence will give you another sweeping view of Lviv, where you can compare the palaces, towers and spires of old Lviv with the Soviet housing blocks of the suburbs.

The castle is a ruin today, and there‚Äôs not much left apart from a wall.
